info.description:
simplified version of the classical 4 interlocked arms.  animated 6-arms variant
[url]https://www.google.com/search?q=4+interlocked+arms&tbm=isch[/url]

Using 4-rotation symmetry folding seems more costly, but 2-rotation is ok.
info.name: Interlocked arms 2 animated

renderpass.code:
// animated variant of https://shadertoy.com/view/ttBBzz

#define rot(a)  mat2(cos(a+vec4(0,11,33,0)))                    
#define P(q)    t = min(t, abs(q.x)+5.),  /* invisible cell wall to fix sign() discont */ \
                r = sign(q.x)*q - vec3(3,0,-1.7)*(.6+2.5*min(T,1.-T)),                    \
                t = min(t, max( 1.-r.z, length(r.xy) - .4 )),  /* arm */                  \
                t = min(t, length( vec2(length(r.yz) - 1., abs(abs(r.x)-.4)-.2)) - .2 ) // 4 rings "fingers" 
  
void mainImage(out vec4 O, vec2 U) {
    
    float t=10.,T=fract(iTime), d;
    vec3  R = iResolution, 
          D = normalize(vec3( U+U, -10.*R.y ) - R ),  // ray direction
          p = 40./R, q,r;                             // marching point along ray 
    O-=O;
    for ( O++; O.x > 0. && t > .01 ; O-=.015 )
        q = p, 
        q.yz *= rot(.6),                              // rotations
        q.xz *= rot(-.3*iTime),
        
        P( q ),                 // P(-q),             // shape with 6 rotations 
        q.xz *= rot(2.1), P(q), // P(-q), 
        q.xz *= rot(2.1), P(q), // P(-q), 
        
        p += t*D;                                     // step forward = dist to obj

    O *= vec4(.8,.8,1,1);                             // coloring
}
